description: Users often perceive aesthetically pleasing design as design that’s more usable. Visually pleasing design can mask usability problems and lead users to believe the design works better.
example: People are more tolerant of minor usability issues when the design of a product or service is aesthetically pleasing. A beautiful interface can make users feel the product is easier to use, even if it’s not.
takeaways: An aesthetically pleasing design creates a positive response in people’s brains and leads them to believe the design actually works better.
People are more tolerant of minor usability issues when the design of a product or service is aesthetically pleasing.
Visually pleasing design can mask usability problems and prevent issues from being discovered during usability testing.
origins: The aesthetic-usability effect was first studied in the field of human–computer interaction in 1995. Researchers Masaaki Kurosu and Kaori Kashimura from the Hitachi Design Center tested 26 variations of an ATM UI, asking the 252 study participants to rate each design on ease of use, as well as aesthetic appeal. They found a stronger correlation between the participants’ ratings of aesthetic appeal and perceived ease of use than the correlation between their ratings of aesthetic appeal and actual ease of use. Kurosu and Kashimura concluded that users are strongly influenced by the aesthetics of any given interface, even when they try to evaluate the underlying functionality of the system.

description: Productivity soars when a computer and its users interact at a pace (<400ms) that ensures that neither has to wait on the other.
example: Provide system feedback within 400 ms to keep users’ attention and increase productivity. Use perceived performance and progress bars to improve response time and reduce the perception of waiting.
takeaways: Provide system feedback within 400 ms in order to keep users’ attention and increase productivity.
Use perceived performance to improve response time and reduce the perception of waiting.
Animation is one way to visually engage people while loading or processing is happening in the background.
Progress bars help make wait times tolerable, regardless of their accuracy.
Purposefully adding a delay to a process can actually increase its perceived value and instill a sense of trust, even when the process itself actually takes much less time.
origins: In 1982 Walter J. Doherty and Ahrvind J. Thadani published, in the IBM Systems Journal, a research paper that set the requirement for computer response time to be 400 milliseconds, not 2,000 (2 seconds) which had been the previous standard. When a human being’s command was executed and returned an answer in under 400 milliseconds, it was deemed to exceed the Doherty threshold, and use of such applications were deemed to be addicting to users.

description: The time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target.
example: Make interactive elements large and close to where users’ attention is focused to reduce the time needed to interact.
takeaways: The time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target.
Make interactive elements large and close to where users’ attention is focused to reduce the time needed to interact.
origins: Fitts’s Law was proposed by Paul Fitts in 1954. It is a predictive model of human movement primarily used in human–computer interaction and ergonomics. The law is based on the speed–accuracy tradeoff, stating that the time required to rapidly move to a target area is a function of the ratio between the distance to the target and the width of the target.

description: The time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices.
example: Minimize choices when response times are critical. Break complex tasks into smaller steps to decrease cognitive load.
takeaways: Minimize choices when response times are critical to decrease decision time.
Break complex tasks into smaller steps in order to decrease cognitive load.
Avoid overwhelming users by highlighting recommended options.
Use progressive onboarding to minimize cognitive load for new users.
Be careful not to simplify to the point of abstraction.
origins: Hick’s Law (or the Hick-Hyman Law) is named after British and American psychologists William Edmund Hick and Ray Hyman. In 1952, they examined the relationship between the number of stimuli present and an individual’s reaction time. The more stimuli to choose from, the longer it takes the user to make a decision.

description: Users spend most of their time on other sites. This means that users prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know.
example: Leverage existing mental models to create familiar experiences. When making changes, minimize discord by empowering users to continue using a familiar version for a limited time.
takeaways: Users will transfer expectations they have built around one familiar product to another that appears similar.
By leveraging existing mental models, we can create superior user experiences in which the users can focus on their tasks rather than on learning new models.
When making changes, minimize discord by empowering users to continue using a familiar version for a limited time.
origins: Jakob’s Law was coined by Jakob Nielsen, a User Advocate and principal of the Nielsen Norman Group. The law states that users spend most of their time on other sites, so they prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know.

description: Elements tend to be perceived into groups if they are sharing an area with a clearly defined boundary.
example: Adding a border or background around a group of elements creates a common region and helps users quickly understand relationships.
takeaways: Common region creates a clear structure and helps users quickly and effectively understand the relationship between elements and sections.
Adding a border around an element or group of elements is an easy way to create common region.
Common region can also be created by defining a background behind an element or group of elements.
origins: The principles of grouping (or Gestalt laws of grouping) are a set of principles in psychology, first proposed by Gestalt psychologists. These principles exist because the mind has an innate disposition to perceive patterns in the stimulus based on certain rules.

description: People will perceive and interpret ambiguous or complex images as the simplest form possible, because it is the interpretation that requires the least cognitive effort.
example: Design icons and graphics using simple shapes to make recognition easier and reduce cognitive load.
takeaways: People will perceive and interpret ambiguous or complex images as the simplest form possible.
Design icons and graphics using simple shapes to make recognition easier and reduce cognitive load.
origins: The Law of Prägnanz is one of the Gestalt principles of grouping, stating that people will perceive and interpret ambiguous or complex images as the simplest form possible. This principle is used in design to simplify complex forms for easier recognition.

description: Elements close together are seen as related.
example: Labels placed near input fields show clear connection.
takeaways: Proximity helps to establish a relationship with nearby objects.
Elements in close proximity are perceived to share similar functionality or traits.
Proximity helps users understand and organize information faster and more efficiently.
origins: The Law of Proximity is one of the Gestalt principles of grouping, first proposed by Gestalt psychologists. It states that objects that are near, or proximate to each other, tend to be grouped together.

description: The human eye tends to perceive similar elements as a complete picture, shape, or group, even if those elements are separated.
example: Color, shape, size, orientation, and movement can signal that elements belong to the same group and likely share a common meaning or functionality.
takeaways: Elements that are visually similar will be perceived as related.
Color, shape, size, orientation and movement can signal that elements belong to the same group and likely share a common meaning or functionality.
Ensure that links and navigation systems are visually differentiated from normal text elements.
origins: The Law of Similarity is another Gestalt principle, stating that the human eye tends to perceive similar elements as a complete picture, shape, or group, even if those elements are separated.

description: Elements that are visually connected are perceived as more related than elements with no connection.
example: Group functions of a similar nature so they are visually connected via colors, lines, frames, or other shapes.
takeaways: Group functions of a similar nature so they are visually connected via colors, lines, frames, or other shapes.
You can use a tangible connecting reference (line, arrow, etc) from one element to the next to also create a visual connection.
Use uniform connectedness to show context or to emphasize the relationship between similar items.
origins: The Law of Uniform Connectedness is a Gestalt principle stating that elements that are visually connected are perceived as more related than elements with no connection.

description: The average person can only keep 7 (plus or minus 2) items in their working memory.
example: Organize content into smaller chunks to help users process, understand, and memorize easily.
takeaways: Don’t use the magical number seven to justify unnecessary design limitations.
Organize content into smaller chunks to help users process, understand, and memorize easily.
Short-term memory capacity will vary per individual, based on their prior knowledge and situational context.
origins: In 1956, George Miller asserted that the span of immediate memory and absolute judgment were both limited to around 7 pieces of information. The main unit of information is the bit, the amount of data necessary to make a choice between two equally likely alternatives.

description: Among competing hypotheses that predict equally well, the one with the fewest assumptions should be selected.
example: Analyze each element and remove as many as possible, without compromising the overall function.
takeaways: The best method for reducing complexity is to avoid it in the first place.
Analyze each element and remove as many as possible, without compromising the overall function.
Consider completion only when no additional items can be removed.
origins: Occam’s razor (also Ockham’s razor; Latin: lex parsimoniae law of parsimony) is a problem-solving principle that, when presented with competing hypothetical answers to a problem, one should select the one that makes the fewest assumptions. The idea is attributed to William of Ockham (c. 1287–1347), an English Franciscan friar, philosopher, and theologian.

description: The Pareto principle states that, for many events, roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes.
example: Focus the majority of effort on the areas that will bring the largest benefits to the most users.
takeaways: Inputs and outputs are often not evenly distributed.
A large group may contain only a few meaningful contributors to the desired outcome.
Focus the majority of effort on the areas that will bring the largest benefits to the most users.
origins: Its origins stem back to Vilfredo Pareto, an economist who noticed 80% of Italy’s land was owned by 20% of the population. The 80/20 way of thinking can provide insightful and endlessly applicable analysis of lopsided systems, including user experience strategy.

description: Any task will inflate until all of the available time is spent.
example: Limit the time it takes to complete a task to what users expect it’ll take. Reducing the actual duration to complete a task from the expected duration will improve the overall user experience.
takeaways: Limit the time it takes to complete a task to what users expect it’ll take.
Reducing the actual duration to complete a task from the expected duration will improve the overall user experience.
Leverage features such as autofill to save the user time when providing critical information within forms.
origins: Articulated by Cyril Northcote Parkinson as part of the first sentence of a humorous essay published in The Economist in 1955 and since republished online, it was reprinted with other essays in the book Parkinson’s Law: The Pursuit of Progress (London, John Murray, 1958).

description: People judge an experience largely based on how they felt at its peak and at its end, rather than the total sum or average of every moment of the experience.
example: Pay close attention to the most intense points and the final moments of the user journey. Design to delight the end user at these moments.
takeaways: Pay close attention to the most intense points and the final moments of the user journey.
Design to delight the end user at these moments.
People judge an experience largely based on how they felt at its peak and at its end, rather than the total sum or average of every moment of the experience.
origins: The Peak-End Rule was first proposed by psychologist Daniel Kahneman and his colleagues. Their research found that people’s memories of experiences are heavily influenced by the most intense (peak) moments and the final moments, rather than the average of every moment.

description: Be liberal in what you accept, and conservative in what you send.
example: Anticipate virtually anything in terms of input, access, and capability while providing a reliable and accessible interface. Accept variable input from users, translating that input to meet your requirements, and provide clear feedback.
takeaways: Be liberal in what you accept, and conservative in what you send.
Anticipate virtually anything in terms of input, access, and capability while providing a reliable and accessible interface.
Accept variable input from users, translating that input to meet your requirements, and provide clear feedback.
origins: Postel’s Law, also known as the Robustness Principle, was formulated by Jon Postel in 1981. It was originally intended for software design, specifically for the implementation of TCP, but has since been applied more broadly to interface and system design.

description: Users have a propensity to best remember the first and last items in a series.
example: Position key actions on the far left and right within elements such as navigation to increase memorization.
takeaways: Users have a propensity to best remember the first and last items in a series.
Position key actions on the far left and right within elements such as navigation to increase memorization.
Place important information or actions at the beginning and end of lists or sequences.
origins: The Serial Position Effect was first identified by psychologist Hermann Ebbinghaus in the late 19th century. It describes the tendency of people to recall the first and last items in a series best, and the middle items worst.

description: Tesler’s Law, also known as The Law of Conservation of Complexity, states that for any system there is a certain amount of complexity which cannot be reduced.
example: Ensure as much as possible of the burden is lifted from users by dealing with inherent complexity during design and development.
takeaways: Tesler’s Law states that for any system there is a certain amount of complexity which cannot be reduced.
Ensure as much as possible of the burden is lifted from users by dealing with inherent complexity during design and development.
Don’t hide complexity at the expense of usability; instead, manage it effectively.
origins: Tesler’s Law is named after Larry Tesler, a computer scientist who worked at Xerox PARC, Apple, Amazon, and Yahoo! He observed that every application has an inherent amount of irreducible complexity, and that designers should strive to manage complexity rather than simply hide it.

description: The Von Restorff effect, also known as The Isolation Effect, predicts that when multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered.
example: Make important information or key actions visually distinctive. Use restraint when placing emphasis on visual elements to avoid them competing with one another.
takeaways: When multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered.
Make important information or key actions visually distinctive.
Use restraint when placing emphasis on visual elements to avoid them competing with one another.
origins: The Von Restorff Effect is named after German psychiatrist and pediatrician Hedwig von Restorff, who first documented the phenomenon in 1933. It is also known as the Isolation Effect.

description: People remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed tasks.
example: Provide a clear indication of progress in order to motivate users to complete tasks.
takeaways: People remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed tasks.
Provide a clear indication of progress in order to motivate users to complete tasks.
Use progress indicators to encourage task completion.
origins: The Zeigarnik Effect is named after Bluma Zeigarnik, a Soviet psychologist who discovered in the 1920s that people remember unfinished or interrupted tasks better than completed ones.

description: A process by which individual pieces of an information set are broken down and then grouped together in a meaningful whole.
example: Chunking enables users to easily scan content. Structuring content into visually distinct groups with a clear hierarchy helps users process information more quickly.
takeaways: Chunking enables users to easily scan content.
Structuring content into visually distinct groups with a clear hierarchy helps users process information more quickly.
Break down complex information into smaller, manageable units.
origins: The concept of chunking was introduced by psychologist George A. Miller in 1956. It refers to the process of grouping individual pieces of information into larger, more meaningful units to improve short-term memory and information processing.
